print_settings.Notes:: If you've got an excellent heated bed (I've got a PEI sheet), you just need to set the bed temperature at 60 degrees for PLA and I've found that it sticks very well with barely any warping and without raft/brim. If you don't have a PEI sheet, you should probably use a brim or a raft if you don't use any methods to make your prints stick to the bed.

description.text:
I had a filament spool that didn't fit the smaller 80 mm cradle because it was about 46 mm wide. I made it by modifying the existing 80 mm mesh in MeshMixer and learned about the software as well. =)
I also added another STL with text on it, so you can easily see what spool size it accepts.

Finally, it is only the cradle, as I haven't included the bearing pins since I've made no changes to them. Just use the other elements from the source to build the cradle!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you've got an excellent heated bed (I've got a PEI sheet), you just need to set the bed temperature at 60 degrees for PLA and I've found that it sticks very well with barely any warping and without raft/brim. If you don't have a PEI sheet, you should probably use a brim or a raft if you don't use any methods to make your prints stick to the bed.

Preface

I designed this with Meshmixer, starting with the STL file for the 80 mm cradle. You can also use the 90 mm cradle.

Step 1 : Separating the middle section

I made two plane cuts to separate the middle part (see the image). This will allow us to scale the middle part only so we don't affect the sections that have the pins. That means we don't have to make new pins.

I used plane cuts to separate the middle section of the cradle. Note that the middle section is already scaled down Step 2 : Scaling down the middle section.

We select the middle section and use the Transform tool (which is in Edit -> Transform or alternatively, press T).
Now, uncheck the Uniform Scaling option.
I prefer to use the size X option to modify the size because it is easier to guess which size you'll end up with. Say, if you remove 10 mm, you know the whole crade will have shrunk by 10 mm since we don't affect the other sections.

Now, after this, it will leave gaps between the middle section and the other two untouched sections.

Step 3 : Stitching all the sections back together.

Now that we have scaled down the middle section, we don't actually need to move the other section back against the middle section. There's a neat little tool where we can snap two pivots together and thus have a precise alignment.

With one of the sections selected, we will use the Create Pivot tool (which is in Edit -> Create Pivot) :
  • In the Create Pivot options menu, make sure that Link to Target is checked. This will attach the pivot to the section we've selected.
  • I typically use Snap To Vertex from the first drop down menu so I can snap to one of the corners of the section.
  • Now, on the selected section, click on one of the corners of the face that is facing the other section you want to snap with (You can see the following gif). Make sure that you've selected the right vertex, if not, you can click somewhere else and it will show you a new pivot.
  • When you are sure of your pivot's position, you can click on Drop Pivot and then Done in the menu.
  • Now, select the other section that you want to snap with and go to Create Pivot tool again.
  • Normally, the options you've previously selected are here again so you can just go ahead and click on one of the corner of the closest face to the other section. Try to use the same corner that you've used for the other section, so that when you snap the two pivots together, they will occupy the same place.
  • When you are sure of your pivot's position, click on Drop Pivot and then Done in the menu.
Now we snap those pivots together!

It's rather easy and all you have to do is Drag and drop one of the pivot and put it on the other pivot. It will show a red line starting from the pivot you started then a ghost image of the piece when you hover the second pivot before you release your mouse button.

Now, in the Align menu, under the Transformation drop down list, make sure to select Translate Only. By then, the two sections should be perfectly stitched together! =)

Finally, you just repeat those steps for the third section and snap it to the middle section.

How to use pivots to snap two section together. This was recorded with LICEcap. =) Step 4 : Combining the objects and exporting to STL

Now that we have stitched our sections together, we can use the Combine to make it a single object.

  • Click on each section while holding Shift. They should all appear brighter and the Edit menu will automatically open.
  • Now, click on Combine.

It should be a single object now. You can verify this by looking up in the Object Browser (It is located under the View top menu, or alternatively you can press Ctrl+Shift+O).

You can also use the Inspector tool to see if there aren't any holes in your object. It is located under Analysis -> Inspector. If there's nothing, it shows nothing. If it does show something, click on the pins that appear to fix those holes.

Finally, you can export it to an STL file. Go to File -> Export (or alternatively, press Ctrl+E), and save it wherever you want. =)

Bonus Step 5 : Making text with 123Design

Now that you've made your new cradle, we can make things a little bit more interesting with some text that show the accepted spool sizes.

Watch the following gif.
A few things to note :

  • After you click on the Text tool, you need to click twice. As far as I understand it, clicking the first time select the plane you want to start from, then the second click is the position of where your text will start, on that plane.
  • I haven't shown the options as you export to STL but you can easily use the Coarse settings. The text print rather nicely on my Maker Select V2 with PLA.
I found it easier to make text in 123Design and export it to STL than using Meshmixer to add text. Bonus Step 6 : Importing the text into Meshmixer

Now that you've exported the text into an STL file, you just need to use the Import button on the left. It will ask you whether you want to append or replace so select Append then browse to your STL file that contains the text.

Now, after you've positioned your text nicely, repeat the step 4 to combine the cradle with the text and then export it to an STL.

Extra Step : Modify your own cradle.

I've included my .mix files in case you'd like to change it. Have fun! =)

description.text:
Since Christmas is over, it's time to put up all of the decorations. I will be placing a lot of mine in plastic bags to help ensure that they aren't chewed on by any pests or collecting too much dust. I made this so that I can zip tie my bags shut and easily cut the zip ties next year without damaging the bag. It will allow me to reuse the bags as long as they are in good shape. Place this on the rolled up end of the bag (rounded side to the bag) and put a zip tie on it. The groove in the piece will give you room to put your cutters in and cut the zip tie without damaging the bag when it comes time to open it back up.

I am sure these will scale up easily if you have very large zip ties.

Designed in FreeCAD 0.16

remixed_from.author: scottan
remixed_from.title: Robo3D top mount offset spool holder

title: Robo3D R1 Offset Top Spool Holder w/ Oiler (w/ Bonus Cable Guide Clip)

description.text:
This is a remix of scottan's top mount spool holder for the Robo3D R1. I made a few usability enhancements for it.

First I changed the spool spindle so it slide in and out with ease. No tight fit problems and no hardware required (for the spindle at least).

Second, I added a bridge. The bridge adds stability to the holder and makes it feel very sturdy.

There are two versions of the bridge, my original (the "v3"), and a new one with a built in Oiler ("v4.1"). Either can be used (and you only need one of them). Both require 4 (four) heat set inserts (#10-32, .225" long) which can be found from McMaster-Carr (https://www.mcmaster.com/#93365a154/=15nkvll). You can find instructions on inserting these at Matterhackers (https://www.matterhackers.com/articles/fasteners-for-3d-printing). I personally prefer using an insertion tip specifically for the inserts instead of a standard soldering tip(https://www.mcmaster.com/#92160a127/=15nkx0d), but that is up to you.

In addition 4 (four) #10-32, 3/4" long flat head screws are needed to attaché the supports to the bridge. For the oiler version you will need a small piece of sponge to shove into the oiler cavity.

I have also included a bonus clip that I use to keep the cable guide for the print head out of the way. It's easy to install and it makes taking the cover on and off much faster.

Note that the offset support is "universal" (there isn't a left/right), so you will need to print 2 of them. :-)

Enjoy!!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 or .3 mm

Infill:

25~50% (use 100% for the cable guide clip

Notes:

I print using PLA. I prefer a 50% infill for anything that will take wear and tear, and that's what I used for my print. The cable guide clip needs 100% infill to be sturdy enough for wear and tear, and so the clip wont break accidentally.

Assembly

To assemble, first insert the heat-set threaded inserts into the bridge you have printed. Once that is done, attach the bridge to one of the two supports and insert the support into the top of the Robo 3D printer. You can then insert the other support and attach it to the bridge with screws.

title: PRINTinZ Plate clips for Printrbot Simple 2016

description.text: Clips to hold down a PRINTinZ Plate (http://www.printinz.com/printinz-3d-printer-plates/) on a Printrbot Simple 2016. Since the design and action of the Simple 2016 does not allow room for metal clips that would go over the edge of the print bed, these clips can be used instead. The clips screw down to the bed via the four threaded holes that are already present on the print bed, and are designed to be left in place when mounting or un-mounting the PRINTinZ Plate. Simply slide the plate in or out horizontally from the front. Assemble the clips with the raised bevel portion of the top piece facing down. When installing, the two smaller clips should be fastened toward the front of the bed to allow clearance with the auto-leveling sensor during the initial filament purge action. The larger clips should be fastened in the rear. These are larger to allow for more clamping strength. Additional parts required: M3 x 10mm screw, qty 4.

I bought this motorcycle led strip light that has both turn signal and brake lights on it: http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/mA2b6E6 I wanted to install it on my bike and the only suitable place that I can find was underneath the saddle. The saddle has two 7mm diameter cylindrical rods spaced 37mm apart. I had to make it curved because of my limited build volume on my Wanhao Di3. It needs one M4 screw to fix to the saddle, it might be tricky to tighten the bolt (I use long spanner). The lights will be controlled by an Arduino. I know this is not a universal solution, I just post it here to share ideas to help anyone who is in the stage of designing their own models (I use Thingiverse a lot to help idea generation). I got the idea from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:195179 Designed in 123D Design.

author: Beginning3dPrinting

title: Interior for a Märklin H0 coach wagon

description.text:
This is an interior for Märklin coach wagons which were not delivered with interior (like the "Silberlingen" 4042 and 4043) .
The original interior is not sold separately and as there are no 3d-designs for this (yet), I decided to measure the original interior and re-design it in Blender.
The original interior is created as a "one-piece" part. However, wagons without interior have a metal partition in the middle, so you have to print it in 2 parts anyhow (or remove the metal partition, but that might destabilize the wagon)
Splitting it up in 4 parts made it possible to mount the interior through the openings in the roof for some models, so you don't have to take the wagon apart.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Supports:

No

Resolution:

normal

Notes: I used bronze filament, as this is close to the original color of some interiors.
You need to print 2 end parts and both the middle part files to fill up a long (24cm) wagon.

The middle section has 2 versions: one with small notches at the end and one without these notches. This is needed because the metal partition inside the wagon has metal flaps which are sticking out a bit.
Depending on the type of wagon there are two ways to mount the interior:
  • older models (with cellophane windows): squeeze the parts through the top. First the middle sections, and then the end sections
  • newer models (with plastic windows): remove the bogie (the thing holding the wheels), bend the metal flaps on the inside at the end which are part of the metal steps. Remove the steps and gently push the bottom to be able to unhook the side panels. After unhooking you can remove the bottom and place the interior.

description.text:
Bonjour a tous, afin de supprimer les bruits de ventillation sur la vertex k8400 et de positionner le ventillateur a l'endroit qui convient,  vous trouverez ci joint un support ventillateur de 40*40 mmm pour une vertex 8400 que je vous conseille de l'imprimer avec un pla flexible afin de faire disparaitre toute vibration lié a un éventuel déséquilibre des pales.  ce support vient s'installer a la place du collier qui sert la nappe.
bon print a tous 
Hello all, in order to remove the noise of ventilation on the vertex k8400 and to position the ventilator in the appropriate place, you will find here enclosed a ventilator support of 40 * 40 mmm for a vertex 8400 that I advise you of the Print with a flexible plate in order to eliminate any vibration related to a possible imbalance of the blades. This support is installed in place of the collier that serves the tablecloth.
Good print at all

comments.text: Bonjour, il te sera quasiment impossible d'imprimer ce type de filament sur une verrtex K8400 d'origine. le support de ventilation présenté a été imprimer avec un Dagoma easy 200 (je vends à 299 euro en kit). le filament est du innoflex 45 . pour l'impression diminuer le débit de matière passer sur des couches a 0,2 , ventiler le corps de chauffe a pleine puissance et diminuer la ventillation de la pièces à 25%.

title: Wing Nut bed level screw knob for Anet A8 (and possibly other printers)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: So you always wanted those nice looking bed leveling knobs all the cool kids have too, but you couldn't afford those expensive M3 nuts needed for all the other designs? Now that's a thing of the past! Introducing the "Wing Nut Bed Level Knob"! Transform your plain looking and painful wing nut into a hip and convenient bed level knob and save $$$! Yeah... so, just use the wing nut that came with the printer if you don't have regular M3 nuts and don't want to run to the store to get some. That's basically it. I suggest using these in combination: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1895223 EDIT: I also added the original design, which bumped into my printer frame since it was slightly too big, but it may be better suited for other printers. I printed this at 0.2mm layer height, without supports. Used brim. Your basic settings should be ok. ADDENDUM: They're supposed to be a tight fit so that they don't come loose easily. I think originally i used pliers to get the wingnuts to snap inside the knobs. I think if you turn them on the bed screws, by tightening them, they might pull the wingnut tightly inside the knob as well. Nevertheless, some people have increased the scale to 104% for a better fit.
YAY! 8000 downloads!
YAY!  13.000 downloads!
In Blender.

comments.text: Great idea, nice construction, but the hole for the screw is a little to small. For a M3 screw the diameter should be 3.2 - 3.4mm :)

I would rather have them too tight than too loose. But you can always run a drillbit or a screw through it to widen the hole if it's a problem for you. Good luck, with a little wiggling, it shouldn't pose a problem to fit these.

title: FT-817 DC-Devil
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The following instruction is only useful for electrically talented people. No liability is assumed for damages resulting from this! The angled plug is used for the power supply of the Yaesu FT-817 and is fixed with a thumbscrew (please remove first the existing grounding screw on the back of the device). The cable used is 2x0.75 mm². If necessary, thinner cable must be wrapped with an insulating tape to ensure a secure hold. The required part of a DC plug (1.7 mm / 4.0 mm / 9.5 mm straight design) (http://www.reichelt.de/DC-Jacks/HS-17-10/3/index.html?ACTION=3&LA=446&ARTICLE=109565&GROUPID=7488&artnr=HS+17-10&SEARCH=HS%2B17-10) is screwed and the connections are shortened to 3 mm. The cable is stripped and soldered approx. 2mm per contact. Before tightening the cover, it is advisable to check the contacts for short-circuit and then secure with a drop of adhesive. In total, an M3x10mm screw, three M3x6mm screws and associated nuts are required. A fuse (2A ) is inserted into the positive line to protect the radio. The universal fuse holder is suitable for holding 5x20mm (European standard) as well as for 6.3x32mm (US standard) fuse. The contacts to the fuse are realized via 5cm bare wire and fixed by a node (see IMG_1372_1.jpg). Optionally, polarity reversal and overvoltage protection can be realized with a suppressor diode (see circuit diagram.jpg). vy 73 es 55 de DH1ND Special thanks to Peter, VK3YE for the inspiration on youtube (Less stress for your FT817's external power connector).
Notes: To remove excess PLA, use a 5mm slotted screwdriver in the recesses on the outsides. It is also recommended to remove PLA residues in the screw thread with a ironfile before assembly.

This is Native American (Sparrow Hawk) Flute with a set of fundamental notes. 12/28/2016
First flute that opens this set has fundamental note C5. I tested the printed flute sample and it perfectly matches to C5 note. The highest note (C6 without overblow) is tuned to higher air flow to play properly. Also next octave is reached by overblow. This 19mm bore diameter may narrow produced notes range, so if some players find this flute does not play up to B6 - this is big diameter consequence. But bigger diameter makes this flute sound more "traditional". 12/29/2016
Second flute has fundamental note A4. The bore diameter 19mm better matches to fundamental note A4. So it shall sound a little bit brighter than C5 for its note. 01/01/2017
Third flute has fundamental note G4. The bore diameter 19mm is at lowest bound for G4. The flute has 3 parts with holes and whistle. 01/06/2017
Fourth flute has fundamental note F4. The bore diameter 22mm matches to fundamental note F4. The flute has 3 parts with holes and whistle. Flute wall thickness is decreased to 4mm, so it requires less plastic and better fit in hands increasing external diameter by 1mm over the previous 19mm bore flutes. 04/15/2017 (v2 is added)
Redesigned holes to make them flat like clarinet holes. This should make the holes location more tactile, and make closed holes more reliable. C5 model has updated 6th hole (1st finger) to sound a litle bit higher - this is based on my previous print. How native american flutes sound with different fundamental notes it can be heard here:
http://www.flutopedia.com/naflutomat_g2.htm
The notes reproduced by the reference are from pentatonic scale. The full finger chart for different fundamental notes can be found here:
http://www.woodsounds.com/fingerCharts.php
https://skybeat.ru/upload/iblock/dca/dca6eb5eb5927c3a6329ebe3737c6e02.jpg (alternative - shows fingering for 18 notes! I checked - it works) Choose proper set of files to print all parts for native american flute.
Choose parts marked as whistle and marked by fundamental note with the same bore diameter specified in mm. E.g. sparrow_hawk_flute_19mm_whistle.stl and sparrow_hawk_flute_19mm_C5.stl to print C5 based flute. Optionally you can choose fetish figure that matches the flute whistle. This model of Native American Flute has alternative construction for air track that is monolitic and thus air leakage free. Fetish figure can be secured on the whistle with Picatinny rail like mount. PS: Rooster fetish figure is a remix from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189558
Eagle fetish figure is a remix from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:450092
Bear fetish figure is a remix from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:192392
Bear head figure is a remix from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1791064 (note, it is available from this page only as a part of the 22mm flute print)
Respect to the authors of the models. You can develop your own fetish figure that better matches to your temper and further use of the flute. I marked this work as not finished since I'm going to add other native american flutes models with different fundamental notes and bore diameters that better match to that fundamental notes.

Notes: Support should not be used to prevent artifacts on the air paths. Sound hole is designed with arc on top of it to allow support free printing. This does not influence how the flute sounds.

Prepare parts for assembly The connection surfaces should be slightly polished (with very thin sand paper). The parts are tightly coupled after inserted to each other, so you probably have only one chance to prepare frictional surfaces to slide smooth. Also I personally use sealant to glue the parts together. Sealant works as librication during assembly and thus helps to connect parts. Then sealant cures in 3-5 days, so the flute becomes mechanically stable.

I designed it in OpenSCAD The theoretical materials are all found by reference http://flutopedia.com/faq_craft.htm
and other references inside.

title: NA Mazda MX-5 Miata Tweeter Bracket

description.text: For NA ('90-97) Mazda MX-5 Miatas (Miatae?) equipped with factory tweeters in the upper door panel. The factory tweeter is embedded in its plastic bracket that secures it to the panel and the back of the silver-trimmed grille, and is impossible to remove. I wanted to install new component speakers in the doors, including new tweeters, while retaining the original appearance. These brackets allow for this - the tweeters snap into place in the bracket and the bracket attaches to the original grille and subsequently the door panel just like the originals. Note: I designed these around the tweeters included with the Infinity PR6500CS speakers. Other tweeters may fit, but I have no way of knowing which they might be. The Infinity tweeters in question measure just over 32mm in diameter and just under 12mm in thickness, excluding the dome. Recommendation would probably be to print in ABS and do a light acetone treatment to ensure the best possible durability. I hate using ABS so I'm going to try PETG and see how it holds up before resorting to ABS - will report back down the road with how that goes.

title: The Bearded Flapper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First, here's a little story about how this thing came about:
So I was trying to find something to remix for the #RemixChallenge. I thought that The Flapper by loubie was pretty cool, so began to look at it's files in Thingiview. I eventually came to the part named "loubie_flapper_dress.stl". I sat there for a good minute or two, staring at the model and wondering why the heck there was a screaming mouth as part of the design. It took me a while, but after re-reading the file name I realized what it was. As I continued looking through the list of #RemixChallenge things, I found The Bearded Yell by bendansie, and, I mean, how could I not make it?
And that's the story! If Bearded_Flapper_full.stl isn't printing correctly, try Bearded_Flapper.stl. Its the same thing, but with out the stand at the bottom.
I added the flapper head to the mouth. You can download it: BeardedFlapperHead.stl I've also uploaded some pictures of it. (The rest of the hair is there, it's just behind the beard.)

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1mm

Notes: I set up a small fan in front of the printer for more efficient cooling. Since it was printed hollow, Fast cooling is a must.
I had to chop off the bottom half to get a successful print. (I did end up making a lot of Angel Hair Pasta in the process)
I was actually very surprised at how well the hair turned out. I expected it to be a big mess, but it ended up being one of my best prints yet!

• I used the Flatten brush to get rid of the existing mouth.
  • I imported the Flapper_Dress, and scaled it to approximately 0.2.
  • I then moved the dress to about where the mouth was.
  • Again using the transform tool,I made some precise adjustments to fit the dress into the mouth.
  • To touch it up, I used the inflate brush around the mouth to fill any gaps.
    • note *I had to chop off the bottom half to get a successful print. You can still download the full version, though (Bearded_Flapper_full).*

WORK IN PROGRESS! I spent several hours designing this frame. Its currently up to Version 7 and I think it's far enough along that I think people could help by giving some design feedback. My current issues are:
Balance - This version of the frame has a similar battery position to the stock frame so I hope that helps with the balance and backward drifting issue from version 6. Arm position stoppers - I need a cleaver/simple/lightweight way to make the arms open to a specific angle. I don't want them to lock but rather a way to stop the arms at the perfect angle. Currently the fit the arms have with the frame is tight and the arms are actually very well held in place but setting that perfect angle is tough without stoppers. Motor wire holders - I need a way to keep the wires neat and free from pinching during folding. For assembly you will need to use some force but not to much because you will break the frame. I've put together several of these so far and only had one arm holder break. Everything is a friction fit and its actually quite tight and works well. Use glue at your own risk but I don't. If you want a good tight fit for everything you will need to do a little sanding. It doesn't take much but it will most likely need it. Version 8 will be in the works once I get a few test flights in and get some feedback from people on here. I print on a glass bed using my Select Mini and it works great. All I use is a skirt and the pieces should stick if you do it correctly. I think using a raft would work too. I print using Hatchbox PLA. Once this is done I want to design a Mavic Pro inspired Nano QX folding frame.

title: darning egg or mushroom, Stopfei oder Stopfpilz
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple darning egg or mushroom, printable without support. At home we had a darning mushroom made of wood and I remembered this useful tool, so I designed one to print on FDM machines (i.e. Ultimaker, RepRap,...). It is designed for function and easy printability and not primarily for good design. I tested it and it works pretty well. And I think the design is at least ok while the Darning egg or mushroom is in the sock (see below for details). ;-) What is a darning egg or mushroom?
A darning egg or mushroom is a tool to help fixing holes in socks. It is a hard, round object mostly made of wood or plastics which is inserted into a sock while darning (repairing) it. The darning egg makes it easier to stitch over the hole. With the help of the darning egg, the sock doesn't get deformed while you stitch, and you will not accidentally stitch two sides of the sock together. How to use it?
You put the darning egg in the sock beneath the hole and stretch the sock and the hole a little bit over the top of the darning egg. While stiching you grab the sock from the outside with the darning egg inside. You hold the darning egg (with the sock around) on the handle with one hand, while with the other hand you stich the hole. With a little practice, in most thicker socks, the fixed hole can be more or less invisible after darning. At least if you use a matching color to the sock for the thread. Here you can find a detailed 'how to' with pictures and video in english:
http://www.wikihow.com/Darn-a-Sock And here you can find a detailed 'how to' with pictures and video in german:
http://www.hauswirtschaft.info/waesche/stopfen.php Perhaps your grandmother also used a darning egg or something similar to fix the holes in the socks. Hope you find it useful, too. Thank you for visiting!
Chris

I printed the darning egg with these settings:
  • no support
  • 0,1mm layers
  • 1mm walls (if you print it without inner support, 1mm or more is recommended for proper finish of the top.)
    • With these settings and 50mm/s speed it prints in about 4h.

title: SD Card Socket (Full-Size) for Hobby Electronics

description.text:
This is a simple friction-fit SD card socket, which uses long-lead female pin headers to breakout the SD pins for your electronics project. Note that the pins broken out are for the 1-bit SPI protocol, not the 4-bit SD protocol. As a result, only seven pins are needed. You will need:
1) The two printed parts
2) 7-pin female pin header, with long springy leads (0.100 inch) Instructions:
1) Print the two parts.
2) Insert your female pin header into the center-ish row of holes, from the bottom. (See photos.)
3) Bend the leads over toward the back edge and shape them to make a springy contact. (See photos.)
4) Ignore the second row of holes, nearest the edge; I was experimenting with using copper wire for contacts but it didn't work.
5) You can either bend the header flat under the socket and glue it in place, or leave it vertical and insert some male-male pin headers to make it breadboard-friendly. (See photos.)
6) Slide the top cap onto the bottom part. It should fit snugly, and your SD card should slide in snugly too. Held in place with friction.

author: sebballl

description.text:
I purchased the servo tester shown in the photo from the internet. It works well but requires a power source to operate which leads to more wires on my workbench that can get in the way. I built a case for this tester that lets you mount a battery pack inside so the unit is mobile.
If you want to build this, do the following:

  • Print out all parts. I printed the button and led covers in a lighter color (I found the leds in this unit to be extremely bright so I wanted to diffuse the light by making covers). I have included the 123D files so you can resize the switch openings to suit the switches you may have lying around.

  • Take apart the blue plastic case the servo controller came in and pull the circuit board off of the rubberized pad it is attached to.

  • I only need to test one servo at a time so I used a pair of wire cutters and cut off the top two rows of servo headers from the circuit board as shown in the photos (the top 2 rows also get in the way of the new case).

  • Glue in a battery pack to the bottom of the case and screw the circuit board to the top of the case using 2 small screws (make sure you first push in the "mode" button you printed off earlier).

  • Wire up the side switch to the battery pack and test it (when you turn on the switch, one of the mode leds should turn on. Test the mode switch to make sure the leds cycle through the modes.

  • I wanted to have a separate power switch that sends power to the servo only when you are ready to do so (switch on top). Attach a servo extension plug to the new case by feeding the wire through the case and soldering it to the servo header (at the same time, have the power wire for the servo go through the switch on the top).

  • Plug in a servo and test it out!
  • I sanded and spray painted my case to get rid of the rough plastic surface.

remixed_from.author: chapulina
remixed_from.title: Rubik's cube for the blind (fully printable)

title: Rubik's Cube Tiles For The Blind (Lesson plan inside)

description.text: Hello Thingiverse. In this design, I have taken the widely popular "Rubik's cube for the blind" and adjusted the files to fit on top of a classic Rubik's Cube. The tiles can be glued on using hot glue or super glue and open a whole new world for people with impaired vision. This model has no special parts or background information needed to put together. I thought that the fully printable version was cool but for people with cheap printers, or little to no DIY experience, this could be easily assembled and used. If you need help on learning how to solve this puzzle, there are many tutorials on YouTube such as this interactive and clear tutorial, or to learn at your own pace, try using this tutorial posted on the Rubik's website. Learning to solve a Rubik's cube can help teach the basics of problem solving, and improve motor skills. It also sharpens memory and quick/critical thinking. Of course this isn't just for blind people; Try to solve it yourself using a blindfold and see how long it takes you! Enjoy!
NGSS

About I have been solving Rubik's cubes for 2 years now and they always seem to fascinate me. There are many methods and tricks to learn when solving them that they become a large hobby. Learning how to solve one has taught me many things about geometry, math, and logical thinking. I used to spend hours a day writing out algorithms for different types of puzzles. I am glad to be able to share such a great learning tool with everyone and make it accessible to the vision impaired to enjoy.

Students should be told that learning how to solve a Rubik's cube takes time and patience, but anyone can learn. Throughout the lesson, encourage them by explaining that it does not take much effort to learn and that most of it is with memory. Instruct them to carefully read step 1 and help them as needed. The first step is arguably the hardest because they don't know what they are doing. Try to explain the layers and turning moves as best as possible. After that, the step with the edges becomes the next hardest part. Here, they must use a combination of letters and translate that into movement of the layers. Make sure you thoroughly go over notation before starting. The top layer is fairly easy, and then orienting the last layer is a challenge. It includes 2 long and complicated algorithms that are easy to learn with repetition. When they are finished, be sure to congratulate them, and then have them try it again.

The needed materials will be a Rubik's Cube for each person (or do it by partners). Classic rubik's cubes are fairly expensive at $15 each, but on there are lots of much cheaper alternatives on Amazon such as this one made by a Chinese company called Shengshou. These ones cost less than $5 each including shipping. Other materials include a printed out PDF of the tutorial, unless you view the steps digitally. Again, the steps can be found here.

• Critical Thinking
  • Logical Thinking
  • Problem Solving
  • Geometry
  • Patience
  • Memory
The lesson should take about 2 hours, but for other people, it can take as long as 3 hours.
If you have any questions about the lesson plan or about anything to do with Rubik's Cubes, please don't hesitate to email me at [email protected]

author: NassAir

title: Plastic carrier bag trash or garbage bin/bag holder

description.text:
This is a bracket that you can use for a small trash bin. It uses the small carrier plastic bags that stores use for your items or any other small plastic bags. It clips on to a drawer or cabinet door for easy access. The bracket has a 20mm wide opening for most wooden drawers or cabinet doors. the .stl file is published for modifications if you so wish.
I might add another bracket and space them evenly. The wedge mount might be resized and reinforced also. (Work in progress)
Update: I made a wider bracket and snipped the corners a bit on the wedge. This should be more stable and easier to assemble.

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20% or more

Notes: Support might be needed for the bottom piece as the slot for the bracket has a bridge. The bracket can 100% infill for more strength. Some sanding or filing of the bracket wedge may be needed for better fit as they are made with the same dimensions.
Here is a similar thing

comments.text: Something very curious. The half-printed piece shown in the photo of my make was sliced using Cura 3.0.4. At 41%, extruder made a hard diagonal move from the back right corner of the model to the middle of the front part of the print. The head then shot back to the position shown in the photo, parked there and stopped. There was also a severe distortion of the infill near the front left corner. Filament stopped flowing and infill was incomplete in a small section of the front rail. This incomplete section was eventually covered by subsequent layers. Printer anomaly perhaps? Tried it again. Same exact thing happened.
comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text: It is indeed very strange, an issue I've not encountered until now. I used to use Cura exclusively and never had this issue either.

remixed_from.author: Leo_N
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Brackets to Reduce X-Axis Motion

description.text: From a design by Leo Nutz... I used Electrico's Anet A8 T-corner (found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1672959) to scallop areas of negative space in order for Leo N's design to be used in combination with the T corners. They're the ultimate combination for frame stability along the X-axis. The T-corner is not included in this design, only used as a visual reference. Note: I haven't personally printed these yet, as I feel Electrico's design provides superior function, at a much lower cost of materials & time resources. However, I know there are folks who like to overkill everything, & this will do it. I scaled the T-corner up by 10% before scalloping the brackets, so there should be a little wiggle room when you mount them. Leo_N's original design found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162

Uh oh. I started designing again without finishing my previous project(s)... Here is a dual hot end mount, specifically, the HE280. It requires minimal modification to the stock effector platform
.
Sure, I could have placed it below the effector platform and not had to worry about cramming everything into the small space, but then you lose height. I never print anything that large, but I dont want to lose it on the off chance i need it. As is, you lose the accelerometer board, so... Its not really a good idea. Maybe it can be moved far above, so the bowden tubes can loop around it. Anyway, Work in Progress. Any and all comments appreciated, This probably wont go any further, but it was a fun couple hours spent playing around.

comments.text: I like the idea! I have the HE280 on my V2. I like the probing feature and the board too much. Maybe you should email this to JJ at seemecnc and see if they have any dial extrusion plans for the future. A modified accel board with this would be an awesome upgrade kit. Nice modeling!

I don't have another extruder stepper yet, so it would be some time before actually implementing this (Id actually like to put a zesty nimble or similar on it), but id love to have dual extruders for soluble support, and maybe colors. comments.text: Electrically?  The connections are OK as shown, provided they go to the correct terminals on the power supply (but that is not shown).  Mine has the hot an neutral on different sides of the switch, but it doesn't really matter.  The green is ground, black is hot, and those follow standard household wiring convention.  The neutral (for 120V use) is usually white but maybe they didn't have white wire so used red instead.  As long as they're going to the correct terminals on the power supply.

1) all firmware supported , marlin sprinter and so on , but Markerbot firmware has not tested . I have tested reprap firmware ,and marlin working well !
2) support mendel and rostock Coordinate System
3) nice GUI
4) console . that means you can control 3D printer with G-code commands just like Printrun PC version.
5)provide some shortcut for leveling the heatbed . Arron is an chinese , so am i .This app will published in Chinese version first ,of course ,and English version will coming soon .Here tips ,you can sent an e-mail to arron to get a copy of source code and mod as you like . Hardware :
bluetooh moudle like :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:138279 (designed by me >_<)

author: MrKindergarten

description.text:
Toothpaste pushers (see the remix source) really come in handy when you have small children in the house that make a mess of the toothpaste tubes.  
Having no 3D printer available to me, I chose to remix this into a laser-cut object.  
The samples are 1/8" transparent blue acrylic, 1/4" would also work.  Wood of any sort is not recommended due to the high humidity in the bathroom, and likelihood of this getting wet.  The graphics are all fill areas designed for raster engraving, and the teeth are highlighted by no engraving, the cuts are the exterior and the mouth slot.   Thanks to user makeplace for easily adapted files, the dimensions of the mouth slot are taken directly from the remix source.
The great white shark mouth fits nicely into our bathroom decor of fish and other sea creatures.
I hope you enjoy!

Printer:

Epilog Laser

title: LimoStudio Flash Strobe Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A cover for the LimoStudio F2530 flash strobe that comes in this kit: https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B005D1OW8C I had trouble storing the flash safely because a delicate bulb sticks out from the end. This cover protects that bulb and allows the flash to be stored in a bag, standing upright on a shelf, or wherever. With the settings below, it came out tight enough to stay on with no danger of falling off, but it is still easy to remove when I pull intentionally. This cover fits my F2530. Based on images online, it looks like it might fit other LimoStudio strobes. It could possibly fit other generic strobes (Neewer, Godox, Flashpoint, etc) but I'm not sure. If anyone lets me know that it fits another strobe, I'll update the description. UPDATES
It fits the Neewer C-250 and the Neewer C-180 (Thanks gnu2000 and adityakejriwal)
Also the Neewer N-300W. (Thanks ad895)

title: Modular remote holder- FireTV (Firestick), Apple TV, Sony Theater

description.text:
These are modular remote holders that snap together like puzzle pieces. After seeing OgreMills's Apple TV holder it inspired me to knocked out some table top holders for my devices. I've designed 3 separate holder for the Apple TV, Fire TV and Sony SoundBar remote. All 3 of these devices have relatively small remotes that always seem to get misplaced so this holder is a good place to store them when you're not using the device. It also displays well on the coffee table when snapped together like puzzle pieces. 
Let me know if you have another device you would like me to add a holder for.
This design is also part of the Remix Challenge so please make sure you click like :)
Enjoy!

description.text:
I found George playing his part in an installation at the front of Dunkers Kulturhus in Helsingborg, Sweden.  George and his Funny Bunny mates made me laugh so hard I fell over.
I asked George the Funny Bunny nicely if he would mind if I took some photos of him and try my luck at making a 3D model in his image so I could look at them every day on my desk.
If anyone can find out who the original artist is please let me know I'd like to give credit.

These files are have not been cleaned or modified from the 123D catch output and may not print well (yet). This is a work in progress, if anyone has luck cleaning the files please let me know.
To use the textured OBJ file you will need to download the Funny Bunny_01.OBJ, Funny Bunny_01.MTL and Funny Bunny_01.JPG files

title: LED Base for Acrylic Edge Lit Sign

description.text:
This is a base for an edge lit LED sign. The design features 2 parts, the main base and the LED strip holder. The holder will print inside the base, on the bed. Once your 5mm wide LED strip is attached to the holder, the holder will snap into the base. The inside roof of the base is at 45 degree angle, to accommodate better printing, and holder has a matching edge, with holes on either side for wiring. The base will hold a 160mm wide acrylic sheet etched with your design. The base measures 180mm x 30mm x 30mm. 
Updated 12/28 - Fixed STL to default right side up (turns out Fusion 360 defaults to Y axis up).

author: bs3

description.text: A minecraft chestplate keychain. Fits great with a keyring.

The Change Trian toy is a Design I made for the Remix Challenge. I felt that since young children are taught to save their money, why not make the saving process fun and educational. When young children are introduced to saving money there is usually a piggy bank involved. Well this toy could be one step in front of putting the coins into the piggy bank. With this toy kids can build a track to their piggy bank for the train to escort their savings too. The train will take the sorted coins from the sorting tower to a piggy bank. Kids will learn the different values, sizes, colors of the four most common United States coins, the penny, dime, nickel, and quarter. General Printing Settings:
Material: Blue PLA
Printhead Temperature: 210 C
Bed Temperature: 60 C
Supports: I did not use supports and everything came out fine
Rafts: I used rafts for every part, but that is just my personal preference
Infill: 25% See PDF for information on the remix, printing guide, and other information on the design. YouTube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WMBScWxXVsk&feature=youtu.be It is not a perfect design, could use some adjustments here and there. I did not design the Lucky Locomotive or the Boxcar's Chassis. The links for those are:
The Lucky Locomotive parts can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274755
The Brawny Boxcar Chassis can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274774 The train track will fit any Chucky Trains that are printed at 65% scale.
Chunky Trains by MakerBot: http://www.thingiverse.com/MakerBot/collections/chunky-trains

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

Notes: See PDF for more printing information when you load the parts into your slicing software you might need to rescale them from mm to inches or inches to mm. The scale factor should be 25.4. This may or may not be needed depending on your slicing software import units.
There were some small imperfections on the parts after printing, much like any 3D printed parts. So I filed and sanded the parts where needed.
Please read the Attached PDF file for how I designed the Change Train Toy set.

title: Yet another J-head mount (for J-head V8 to Prusa i3)

description.text:
This Thing is a decent little mount + fan holder + blower/layer fan shroud + sensor holder combo I came up with to mount my (genuine) J-head V8 onto my Prusa i3's X carriage. This differs from most other designs I've seen here because it's designed to facilitate an upgrade from a direct, motor-on-the-X-carriage extruder (ala Stepstruder and similar) to bowden-feed J-head. As such, it fits the 30 mm bolt pattern found in those kinds of setups (as in my case), rather than the 28 mm bolt pattern found on the vanilla Prusa i3 X carriage. There is a (split) threaded hole on top for a PC4-M6 push-fitting. The front bolt pattern and shroud inlet fit a common "5015" type centrifugal blower. The "sensor" refers to an 18mm inductive sensor commonly used for Z-probing and auto-bed-leveling. Assembly
Wrap a layer of electrical tape or a couple layers of kapton tape around the J-head's slot mount (but trim the tape narrow to keep it off of the vents), place it between the two "front"/"back" pieces, squeeze them together, and thread your main mounting screws through the two pieces and through your X carriage. Before you tighten those screws, take a look at the brass heat block and heater cartridge in your J-head. You'll notice that the heat block is off-center relative to the nozzle. Orient the J-head so that the block is offset toward the front of the machine (this puts the heater cartridge parallel to the X axis and positioned toward the front). Tighten those main mounting screws snug, but not completely yet. Thread the PC4-M6 fitting into the hole on top, making sure it's perfectly aligned, and tighten the two mount screws to clamp everything together. You want these to be torqued down kinda hard, but don't over-tighten them so much that you damage anything. Once you have those pieces clamped together, drop an M3 nut into the trap in the blower shroud's left-side mount, and fasten it via a suitable screw to the corresponding mount on the "back" block. Next, install the blower onto the "front" block. It should be pretty obvious how it goes on. :-) Next, drop a couple more M3 nuts into the traps in the right-side mounts on the shroud and "back" block, and use them to secure the cold end fan, positioned to blow inward. Note that this fan also serves as a light structural support for the shroud. Lastly, mount the inductive sensor into its hole, taking care to get the vertical position (and hence its sensing height) right for your particular bed. Vitamins:
You will need three M3 nuts and suitable screws to mount the cold-end fan and to join the shroud to the mount block, and two M4 nuts and suitable screws for the blower fan. You may need to add a washer or two to the upper screw on the cold-end fan. You'll also need two longer M3 screws, nuts, and some wide washers to mount the assembly to your X carriage. I'm not sure how long the ones I used are, probably 45 mm. And of course, the aforementioned PC4-M6 fitting. Etc.
I use this along with my "B'Wadestruder" extruder design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1831961). The pictures shown here are of an earlier revision of this Thing (only minor adjustments needed made before publishing -- just tightened-up the nut traps and slightly re-worked the joint between the shroud and the block). About the tape mentioned above: I deliberately made the slot mount very slightly over-sized, so that you could fill in the gap with some kind of tape. This is to provide extra friction with less clamping force, so that the J-head can't spin/turn in the mount (imho, this is better than trying to clamp down hard on the PEEK itself).

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: The shroud part has an inner lip that is meant to be torn/cut off after printing (it's just there to make sure the center parts of the shroud stick well to your build plate). You'll also want to remove the two little support objects inside the "front" part's countersink holes. You'll need rotate the "front" and "back" parts so that they lay flat on the bed. Print slow and print cool, you'll need decent bridging performance for the top-inside of the blower shroud to print properly.

I started by taking several measurements and drawing a simple model of my J-head in Blender, then imported pieces from some other projects (such as the fans, X smooth rods, bearings, X carriage -- which has the wrong hole pattern in the .blend, by the way, etc).
Then I...um...drew the rest. :-)
Please note that I did not draw the two fans nor the X carriage shown in .blend file.  I don't remember where I got the fans, but the X carriage model is from Prusa's vanilla distribution.

title: Magic: The Gathering Kaladesh Servo Creature Token (3-Counter Holder) MtG #MtGCounters

description.text: This servo creature token is designed for token creatures summoned in the Kaladesh set. It is based on my basic creature token (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1990847) and is designed to hold up to three of my Magic: The Gathering Counters (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1815081). The 3-counter token allows you to assemble your counters into creatures. Want to make a +2/+2 creature with flying and haste? No problem. Want to make a +2/+1 green-mana creature? You can do it with this. Pictured is a +4/+4 red-mana creature with lifelink. The token looks best printed in gold or bronze, but yellow was all I had available at the time. The spoke of slightly longer length indicates the front. To tap, simply turn 90 degrees. If you want to specify mana color and save a slot, you can just print the token in the color of the mana. (For example, for black mana, print a black creature token.) The possibilities of creature token shapes are endless. There could be angels, dragons, servos, you name it. I would LOVE it if people would remix this basic holder into other creatures. If you do, tag it with MtGCounters and make it a remix of my basic token (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1990847).

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

45 percent.

Notes: I HIGHLY recommend printing at .2 layer height. I can't guarantee good results with .3 height. The counters are designed to stack easily on top of the 3-counter token. That being said, you might need to adjust your printer settings to get them to print just right. To get a good fit: In Slicer, I recommend printing perimeters first. In Cura Standalone Version, I recommend tweaking horizontal expansion.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1989965 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1989965
Using the following options:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1989965 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1989965
Using the following options:

Printing in PLA makes me happy :)
PLA that skips on the hobbed bolt due to the extruder stepper getting too hot makes me sad :( This is a cooler for the UP / Afinia extruder stepper.
From a 40mm fan, this surrounds the stepper motor with cool air on both sides and finally diverting the air upwards to not make ABS prints warp.
It almost completely encases the stepper from underneath as well to block the hot air from the heaterblock. UPDATE: added a snorkel for the other side of the 40mm fan so that it dosen't pick up hot air blown off the heaterblock. PRINT THIS! It really makes a big difference! UPDATE 2: Added Pro-Desktop file for Adam. :)

When printing, you'll need to rotate this 180 degrees so that the fan hole sits flat on the build platform.
Minimal support will be needed unless you have uber-leet air printing skills. There is also space inside for a small stick-on heatsink on the back of the stepper.
I've also included some photos of a recommendation -
Get yourself some high-temp automotive silicone and cover around your heater block with about 2mm of thickness, making sure not to coat the tip, wiring entry side or the stem.
I've found this to greatly speed up the heatup time of the block, and also minimise heat that gets blown off the block and towards the stepper from the original UP cooling fan (not shown). UPDATE: added a snorkel for the other side of the 40mm fan so that it dosen't pick up hot air blown off the heaterblock.
Print snorkel upright if you want to minimise support material. If you have any queries or comments - let me know! :)

comments.text:
Hi Julia! Cheers!
It's meant to be a slide-on friction fit. If you're worried about it sliding off during use, you could use a bit of doubled over kapton underneath the stepper to hold it in place. But, I have made these for three UP's and have not had a problem with normal slide-on :-)
comments.author: JuliaTruchsess

comments.text:
I can confirm that, it is a really good friction fit. I have no worries that it will come off during print.
Just have an other question. When I look at your pictures I believe I have a different extruder setup. When I placed your stepper cooler on my extruder I noticed a 'gap' at the front of the stepper motor, showing the metal wheel that squeezes the fillament against the fillament drive gear.
You can see this in the picture in the link (its not my printer and it is not your stepper cooler though!) http://s28.postimg.org/7re2dkb1p/image.jpghttp://s28.postimg.org/7re2dkb...
I was thinking that maybe instead of leading the airflow at the front up and away it might be a good idea to lead it directly in to the gap (or 'around' the motor) so some air is getting directly near the drive gear.
I also was thinking that it would be better to place some heatsinks on the side of the stepper motor (the black part of the stepper motor). So making one side of the stepper cooler thicker, so that a small ram heatsink fits underneath it.
Could I pm you so that you can send me a 3d file i can edit?
comments.author: Dogbert

comments.text:
Howdy.
There are some good ideas you have. I do agree with making the outer side vent a bit wider to put a small heatsink on tbe side of the stepper. I made the licence on this as creative commons and I've uploaded the Pro-Desktop file - go for it! Edit to your liking :-). Can't wait to see the mod!
Although i think it's a good idea to try to get some air into that 'gap' - there have been plenty of people that have made air tube inlets at the top to inject air down to where you're saying. It would probably do a better job than the 40mm fan at the back. I designed this so that you could run both (someone's air tube design and this). Also, if you have a good enough 40mm fan this should negate ever needing to inject air in the front because the gear on the front of the stepper gets warm in proportion to the stepper. This stops rhe stepper getting warm in the first place and thereby keeps the gear cool.
But, like i said, i encourage mods! Go for it! I'll definately try yours out as well :-)
If you have any other queries, feel free to pm me.
comments.author: xr3dhub

comments.text:
Before I can modify I need to get my hands on pro desktop. I did test your original design. First I tried it with the snorkel but I noticed when I put the snorkel on the airflow gets reduced significantly. After removing the snorkel there was much more airflow. So I think a wider snorkel is needed.
Unfortunately I'm not able to print PLA with this mod. I must say that the stepper motor runs much cooler, after an hour print I can touch the motor, it's warm but not to hot to touch. But when the 1,5 hour print was done, I noticed that already in the first 30 minutes extrusion had stopped and the motor started skipping.
Don't really know what the issue is now. Probably be that the motor still is to hot for the PLA. I could try a different PLA supplier, but I don't really feel like wasting money on a new spool....

comments.text:

comments.text:
Hi, how did you wire up the second fan ? Is it just connected to a separate 12Vdc supply, connected to the other fan on the head ?
Are you printing generic PLA or the specific UP PLA ?
comments.author: Dogbert

comments.text:
The second fan goes to a separate 12v power supply (just a standard wall wart).
Both the printer and this power supply are plugged into a master/slave powerboard.
Master - 3d Printer.
Slave - power supply.
When the printer powers up, the powerboard automatically powers up the fan.
I use generic PLA - genuine UP stuff is sofa king expensive!

comments.text: Very interesting mod! What are your results on the long term? Can you say this mod is effective? How long are you able to print with PLA?
comments.author: Dogbert

comments.text:
Results long term - VERY effective! I've quite often slipped off this
cooler 3/4 of the way through a big print and the stepper is only
mid-warm, in comparison to without - where I couldn't touch the stepper
because it was that hot. I can print with PLA for 15hr prints without a
problem!
As far as skipping - I have noticed the cooler may have been
working so well that it masked one other fault with my printer - my
print head hasn't been heating up as much of late. Not sure why -
possibly heater or sensor module getting old. It would have started
skipping a long time ago if it wasn't for this cooler! Now my print head
temp is so low with PLA that it skips regardless due to not melting the plastic! :(
Gotta replace the head now, or do Ktronic's trick and run my printer on ABS mode for PLA.

A set of four pyramids, called Painter's Points, to use to hold up things that you paint. This lets you paint the bottom, then flip the thing over, put it on the points, and keep painting. This lets you paint the whole thing at one time, making it about twice as fast as painting the bottom, letting it dry, then flipping the thing over and painting the top.

Print with 0% infill, two shells.
  • Paint the bottom of your thing.
  • Arrange the painter's pyramids in a rectangle smaller than the base of your thing.
  • Flip your thing over and put it on the points of the pyramids.
  • Paint the rest of your thing.
  • Point out to your Significant Other that you printed these faster and cheaper than driving to the hardware store and buying them.

description.text:
Anyone that’s ever play some 80’s videogame in their life has probably fantasied at one point or another about what it would be like to live in a classic arcade game. (Pac-man or Space invader)
Do you remember?
Well now you can feel  exactly that and step into your very own videogame world with these amazing ‘Pixel shoes” that look exactly like they have been plucked straight out of a some classic videogame.
The “Pixel shoes” can be printed with a varying degree of infill, meaning you can make them softer or harder based on your needs.
According to Ignacio, it only takes approximately 10 hours to print out an shoes (46EU) on the prusai3 3D printer, with a large crystal bed. (Add a 315mm bed/ no need heatbed)
You can use every color you want or use 2, 3, or more colors in the shoe. Look how it looks 3D printed sole in Blue FilaFlex and the rest of the shoe in Black, the combination is infinite. (46EU size)
These shoes are super cool and with unique design that will be turning heads everywhere you go.
What are you waiting for? Print you own Pixel shoes!
Notes: 3D printers: Prusa Steel BCN 3D printer

PRINT SETTINGS:
Filament: FilaFlex Filament 
Print speed: 50 mm/s
Fill density: 25%
Layer Height: 0,25 mm
Temp: 220ºC
Support Type: Everywhere.
Perimeter: 40
Angle support: 70
No need heated bed or hairspray

Designed by Recreus founder Ignacio Garcia, the “Pixel Shoes” are inspired by  minecraft and classic videogames. Ignacio explained that he used the Meshmixer software for this project, which allowed him to create this amazing “Pixel” texture looks like something out of a movie or video game.

comments.text:
I just wanted to share my experience in this. I did not build this extruder but my own using the same steppers. I apparently build my delta robot too big, and I had problems with pushing the filament through the 2m teflon tube, there was too much friction or something.
I made a new extruder with 2pc 28BYJ-48. The steppers are modified for bipolar, to gain max torque. Drivers are stepsticks, adjusted to 190mA. Motors are 5V driven at 12V to gain speed.
The 2 steppers are driven in parallel, one turning the opposite way. Both motor shafts are directly coupled into a MK7 gear, spring loaded bearing on the opposite side. It is pushing the filament down into a J-head.
I have not made long term testing, my printer is not running correctly yet, but the extruder seems to work. I think it works reliable at 70mm/s, It begins to skip at 80. The motors are not getting warm and I have no active cooling, so faster speeds may be possible.
My prototype is made of stainless steel, I have not measured the weight, but my calculation says about 200g, a lighter version should be possible with plastic.

comments.text:
Has anyone build this extruder and tested it? I wonder how long the plastic-gears inside will last. I also played around with these steppers some month ago and have some lying around.
I modified one (cut centerpoint-trace) and let it run about 60 hours without load at about 10 rounds/min which seemed to be the highest possible rpm before it starts stalling. Sometimes it lost few steps when getting hot, but after 60 hours the plastic gears inside just looked fine.
I used the 5V model with a A4988 Pololu powered by a 12V supply (5V unipolar with cut centerpoint-trace -> 10V in bipolar configuration, so 12V should be ok). My power supply said the whole setup (Arduino Nano + Pololu + Stepper) consumed about 200mAmps when running. While running, the motor temperatur (measured on several points on the outside) did not exceed 55°C.
Any ideas of how much torque this motor could deliver? Rumors say, there should also exist identical motors with brass gearing inside.

comments.text: use ucn5803 driver chip... it needs only step and direction ,,, u can hook it to ramps directly... also i have used these motors before and they don't have enough torque to drive a extruder....
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: Yes that chip might work, if you only feed it 5V. You can also drive it from a regular pololu/stepstick already on your ramps board, just make sure the current is set super low (~100mA). The gearing on this motor determines how much torque it has, it may just be enough for an extruder. How much force you need for an extruder depends on the diameter of the filament, the nozzle opening, the temperature you print at (or better the viscosity of your melt) and the speed you are printing with.

comments.text: yes you need 5v for the driver chip, also the torque is good enough only for 1.7mm filament and not more than 30mm/s extrusion speed max...i think a dual motor setup might just work... need to try though

comments.text: This could be used in a hybrid bowden/direct extruder I read about a while ago on the reprap forums. You have a big NEMA17 pushing on the filament providing the majority of the force, and a tiny 28byj in effect just "regulating" the feed to the nozzle. You could just break out 4 wires from the RAMPS aux outputs and use the uln2004 driver that's typically included with them. Although, you'd have to write your own support into the firmware...
comments.author: jamesgao

comments.text: It is quite easy to drive these motors once you break the trace in the center of the motor.  The blue cover just pops off and you can then easily cut the trace connecting the common returns for both coils.  Set your electronics to their lowest current settings and that should be enough power to drive them.   These motors are very picky, and the steps per mm settings are very low, but they work perfectly once you get it set right... And they're cheap. (I bought a few hundred of them for less than $1 each a while back on AliExpress.)
comments.author: Lil3d

comments.text: You don't need to break the trace, just ignore the red wire, then colours for ramps will be pink, orange, yellow, blue
comments.author: Lil3d

comments.text:
You can drive a Unipolar as a bi-polar by just skipping the feed line in this case the red wire!
But it is a 5 Vdc stepper so you need a power converter!
comments.author: Jsahib

comments.text:
No, you do not need to convert the voltage, unless you are driving your stepper with a (very old) unregulated driver. Modern drivers like pololu's regulate the current that goes trough your stepper. That way you can (and should!) connect to a higher voltage than nominal, which makes microstepping and higher speeds possible.
You have to be careful with this motor though to not feed it too much current. The usual 500mA fries it within seconds, at 100mA it gets hot but continues working. .
comments.author: Jsahib

comments.text: so will this actually drive filament, they are kind of weak
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: I've considered playing with these motors before, but always decided against it because they were 5-wire unipolar and thus incompatible with bipolar stepper drivers. If you break off that plastic case, there may be a small PCB inside with traces connecting the center taps of the two windings. If you cut that trace and remove the wire attached to it, you should have a bipolar stepper.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text:
One way to find out which wires are connected in a coil is to use a multimeter. Remember that a coil is effectively a piece of wire and should read very low resistance across two wires that are the two ends of a single coil.
I have a couple of these motors and my base concern would be that they are excruciatingly slow. Would be cool to see if it works though, so please update us of your results.

I am assuming that you have bought the motor with the driver PCB, If so then you should be able to remove the 'E' smart step board, (or just add wires if no smart step PCB) and some jumpers from:
Clock,

and get an L297, or if you have electronics/software knowledge, program up a small micro !

comments.text: just ignore the centertap wire and it will work anyway. beware that these motors can only take a little current (~100mA) lest they burn out.
comments.author: ceri

comments.text: Two types of step motors. Yours is unipolar. This means that you have a 5th wire, the red coloured one. Completely ignore the red wire. This means that you will be using it as if it were a bipolar motor, which is the 4 wire type that RAMPS boards are designed to drive.
comments.author: zzzomb

comments.text:
I am fairly sure that some damage will occur if you connect a uni-polar wound motor to a bi-polar driver,
After all the second phase will have half the drive voltage applied to its power transistors,
a very near short to Gnd, or 12 Volts,
comments.author: zzzomb

comments.text: And I am fairly sure no damage occurs as I have driven this type of motor successfully from a pololu stepper driver. The problem is that even the lowest setting on the pololu was a little too much current for the motor. SO the first one fried (incidentally, with said centerpoint trace cut), but the second held out (with the centertap intact but not connected). If you run this with microstepping you might get some crosstalk effects due to the (virtual) voltage on the coils being different, I guess you get a reduced resolution, but that is hardly relevant for an extruder motor.
comments.author: ceri

description.text: xmas ornament

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini BB Spool Holder

description.text:
At what point does something stop being a "remix" and become its own thing? I don't know, but this design incorporates elements of thing 1636941, thing 1989704 and my own work added in 123Design and TinkerCAD. Here are the links to the original items: MP Select Mini small spool holder by rixkix:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1636941 Fillament Holder (For Kossel Alt) by Homexperts:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1989704 It is a remix? A mashup? I don't know, but I can't take sole credit for a design that is more other people's work than my own. With that said, there are a ton of filament holders for the Monoprice MP Select Mini 3D printer, and none of them met my expectations. Some were close, some were only for "mini" rolls, some just didn't work well. This holder is about the same size as the stock filament holder and uses the factory mount. This filament holder uses ball bearings so the filament rolls out freely, has guides to keep the spool in place and is even branded with the Monoprice IIIP logo. When it's mounted on the printer, it looks like it came with it. I printed this with Simplify3D due to its excellent supports. In my opinion Simplfy3D creates the best supports and they come off cleanly. For me, Cura always left behind a mess that was hard to clean up. Keep this in mind when choosing a slicer for this piece. You will need 2 x 608zz ball bearings for this to work. (It works as well as stock without them, but I strongly suggest the ball bearings. Edit: At the behest of a friend I tried something. Much to my surprise, these 3D printed bearing shapes actually work quite well, not anywhere near as well as a real bearing, but surprisingly well: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:325847

• MP_mini_BB_spool_holder.V1.0.stl - The original - somewhat narrow - only works with some spools.

  • Flipped_MP_mini_BB_spool_holder.V1.0.stl - The original - flipped upside down for fewer supports.

  • MP_mini_BB_spool_holder_20mm_extended.stl - modified version with 20mm extra space for larger spools

  • MP_mini_BB_spool_holder_25mm_extended.V2.0.stl - Version 2.0 with 25mm extra space, but overall length shortened to 120mm so it will print on the stock mini bed. See the images for a Cura screenshot that shows how to align it for printing.
    • Note: If you're confused about which one to print, try #4. Sorry about all the different versions, however I'm trying to help people out with their specific needs.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.175mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Printed on the Monoprice MP Select Mini 3D in White Monoprice PLA Plus+ @ 210°C with an unheated build plate on 3M Blue Painter's Tape. (No adhesives)

comments.text: There are really two ways to print it - right side up or upside down. Right side up wastes a lot of material on supports, but it puts the supports on the bottom of the piece so you can be sure it looks good. Upside down would probably reduce the support material greatly, but it might cause the visible and functional areas to not look/work as good.
